pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 247, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 343, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 358, 504, 373]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 373, 892, 402]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 400, 384, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 429, 892, 460]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 459, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 517, 765, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 549, 359, 564]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 564, 630, 579]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

The water is stirred until the temperature of the water has fallen to \(0^{\circ}\mathrm{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 537, 361, 556]]<|/det|> 18 g of ice remains unmelted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 570, 514, 587]]<|/det|> The specific heat capacity of water is \(4.2 \text{ J} /\text{ g} ^{\circ}\text{C}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 599, 787, 617]]<|/det|> Which value does this experiment give for the specific latent heat of fusion of ice? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 133, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 628, 220, 645]]<|/det|> 210 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 628, 291, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[303, 628, 388, 645]]<|/det|> 330 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 628, 460, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 628, 551, 645]]<|/det|> 580 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 628, 631, 645]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 628, 720, 645]]<|/det|> 770 J/g <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 673, 106, 691]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 490, 691]]<|/det|> In which does thermal conduction **not** occur? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 701, 134, 720]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 702, 201, 720]]<|/det|> a gas <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 728, 134, 746]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 728, 215, 746]]<|/det|> a liquid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 755, 134, 772]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 755, 210, 772]]<|/det|> a solid <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 781, 134, 798]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 781, 237, 798]]<|/det|> a vacuum

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 109, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 408, 88]]<|/det|>
The metal surface of a kettle is hot.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 885, 120]]<|/det|>
What happens to the cool air outside the kettle when it comes into contact with the hot kettle?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 129, 134, 147]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 129, 556, 147]]<|/det|>
The density of the air decreases and the air falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 156, 134, 175]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 156, 561, 175]]<|/det|>
The density of the air decreases and the air rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 183, 131, 201]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 183, 549, 201]]<|/det|>
The density of the air increases and the air falls.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 210, 133, 227]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 210, 556, 227]]<|/det|>
The density of the air increases and the air rises.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 254, 107, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 254, 922, 287]]<|/det|>
Some hot water is sealed inside a metal can. The can is in a vacuum in outer space. The hot water slowly cools down.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 298, 529, 317]]<|/det|>
How does the thermal energy escape into space?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 327, 134, 345]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 327, 400, 345]]<|/det|>
by conduction then convection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 354, 134, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 354, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
by conduction then radiation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 380, 134, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 380, 413, 397]]<|/det|>
by evaporation then convection

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 406, 133, 425]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 406, 395, 424]]<|/det|>
by evaporation then radiation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 450, 106, 467]]<|/det|>
<label>20</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 450, 546, 467]]<|/det|>
When water waves pass through a gap they diffract.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 479, 601, 498]]<|/det|>
The diagrams show wavefronts approaching a narrow gap.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 836, 546, 853]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 485, 873, 504]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 512, 873, 530]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 539, 920, 572]]<|/det|>

charge on stripsforce between strips
Aoppositeattraction

counts per minute
none95
